title: Magnetic Mountain

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of oil on canvas.

description: After Kurt Seligmann settled in Paris, his sinister, biomorphic compositions gained the attention of André Breton, who invited him to join the Surrealist group in 1937. With the outbreak of World War II, Seligmann became the first Surrealist to arrive in New York and was instrumental in the emigration of most of the movement’s leading figures. Transformed by contact with new cultures, Seligmann’s work continued to evolve, and as the Surrealists’ acknowledged expert on magic, he infused his paintings with mythology and esotericism. Indeed, the year he made this work, he published The Mirror of Magic, a history of the occult. The winding forms and mystical quality of this canvas would influence a new generation of American artists, including his student, Robert Motherwell.
publication_history:
Painting in the United States, 1949, exh. cat. (Carnegie Institute, 1949), cat. 101.

Derrière le miroir 49, no. 19, special issue Kurt Seligmann (Galerie Maeght, 1949).

Belle Krasne, “‘Expressionism, Abstraction, Surrealism’ Predominate at the Whitney,” The Art Digest 24 (Nov. 15, 1950): p. 12 (ill.).

Hermon More, 1950 Annual Exhibition of Contemporary American Painting, exh. cat. (Whitney Museum of American Art, 1950), n.p. (ill.); cat. 119. 

Art Institute of Chicago, Annual Report 1981-82, p. 38.

Stephan E. Hauser, Kurt Seligmann 1900-1962: Leben und Werk, exh. cat. (Schwabe & Co. AG, 1997), pp. 300; 301 (color ill.); 442, cat. 251.

Timonty Baum, Stephan E. Hauser, Stephen Robeson Miller, Martica Sawin, Meyer Schapiro, and Kurt Seligmann, Kurt Seligmann: First Message from the Spirit World of the Object, exh. cat. (Weinstein Gallery, 2015), p. 70 (ill.).

Hank Hine, with William Jeffett, Peter Tush, Shaina Harkness, Allison McCarthy, and Kelsey Hallbeck, The Shape of Dreams Five Centuries of Painted Dreams, from the Devine, Mythological, & the Mind,, exh. cat. (St. Petersburg, FL: The Dali Museum, 2022), 22, 23 (color ill.), 128-29 (color ill.), 143.
exhibition_history:
Pittsburgh, Carnegie Institute, Painting in the United States, 1949, Oct. 13–Dec. 11, 1949, cat. 101.

Paris, Galerie Maeght, Kurt Seligmann, Apr. 1949.

New York, Whitney Museum of American Art, 1950 Annual Exhibition of Contemporary American Painting, Nov. 10–Dec. 31, 1950, cat. 119.

Art Institute of Chicago, Mary and Earle Ludgin Collection, Sept. 11–Oct. 31, 1982.

Kunsthaus Zug, Kurt Seligmann, Nov. 23, 1997–Feb. 15, 1998.

St. Petersburg, FL, Salvador Dalí Museum, The Shape of Things, Nov. 25, 2022–Apr. 30, 2023, no cat. no.
provenance_text: The artist; Mary and Earle Ludgin, Hubbard Woods, 1950 [letter from Kurt Seligmann to Mary and Earle Ludgin, Oct. 11, 1950, Earle and Mary Ludgin Papers, Reel 3822, Earle and Mary Ludgin Papers, 1930-1983, Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution; copy in curatorial object file]; given to Art Institute of Chicago, Oct. 22, 1981.
